#Text=Frederick Frank ( businessman )
#Text=Frederick Frank ( born May 31 , 1932 , Salt Lake City , Utah ) is an investment banker , with more than 50 years of experience on Wall Street .
#Text=He is considered the first investment banker to have specialized in the areas of biotechnology , pharmaceuticals , and health care services . [ 4 ] [ 5 ]
#Text=As of 2014 , Frank became a founder and chair of EVOLUTION Life Science Partners .
#Text=He previously served as vice chairman of Lehman Brothers , Barclays Capital , and the Peter J. Solomon Company . [ 4 ]
#Text=He is credited as lead underwriter for over 125 IPOs and as a negotiator in over 75 mergers and acquisitions . [ 6 ]
#Text=Frank was chosen as one of the top 100 contributors to biotechnology in 2005 . [ 5 ] [ 7 ]
#Text=Early life and education
#Text=Frederick Frank was born on May 31 , 1932 , [ 8 ] to Simon Frank and Suzanne ( Seller ) Frank of Salt Lake City , Utah .
#Text=He ran a men 's wear business established by his father , Arthur Frank . [ 9 ]
#Text=He completed high school at Hotchkiss School in Lakeville , Connecticut in 1950 . [ 8 ] [ 10 ] [ 3 ]
#Text=Frank graduated in the class of 1954 from Yale University with a degree in philosophy . [ 11 ]
#Text=He served in the U.S. Army in Europe from 1954-1956 , much of the time in Paris , France at Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers Europe ( SHAPE ) . [ 8 ]
#Text=After returning to the United States , he received an MBA from Stanford Graduate School of Business in 1958 . [ 10 ] [ 12 ]
#Text=Career
#Text=In 1958 , Frank joined Smith , Barney and Company .
#Text=He chose to accept their offer because they had a highly ranked research department .
#Text=After completing the required formal training program , Frank joined the research department to work with Bill Grant on the pharmaceutical and chemical industries .
#Text=He soon proposed splitting the two areas , and became Wall Street ’s first industry analyst dedicated to pharmaceuticals .
#Text=In 1962 , he shifted focus to the life sciences industries , dealing with medical devices , diagnostics companies , and healthcare services . [ 12 ]
#Text=He held the positions of co-leader of research , vice president , and director at Smith , Barney . [ 5 ] [ 12 ]
#Text=In October 1969 , Frank left Smith Barney and joined Lehman Brothers , the first person from outside the organization to join it at the level of partner .
#Text=Leaving research and analysis , he shifted to investment banking , handling capital investment and mergers and acquisitions .

#Text=Frank is credited with creating original and at times unprecedented structures that have connected innovative early-stage research-oriented companies with larger development and market-oriented pharmaceutical corporations . [ 12 ]
#Text=In 1978 , Frank led a team at Lehman Brothers , handling Humana 's acquisition of American Medicorp .
#Text=The team included Mary Catherine Tanner , a recent graduate from Harvard University . [ 12 ]
#Text=Frank convinced her to join his team at Lehman .
#Text=Ten years later , on October 15 , 1988 , they were married . [ 3 ]
#Text=Frank became vice chair of Lehman Brothers in 1995 . [ 11 ]
#Text=Tanner became senior managing director . [ 1 ]
#Text=Frank and Tanner worked together at Lehman for over ten years , until Tanner took time off to have a child . [ 2 ]
#Text=In the late 1970s , Frank began to work with companies such as Cetus , a company developing industrial applications for Recombinant DNA technology , and Genentech .
#Text=Frank saw rDNA technology as a " game-changing opportunity " . [ 12 ]

column1: #Text=Advised by Frank , Cetus went public on March 1 , 1981 with the second-largest IPO in U.S. corporate history . [ 12 ]
#Text=Frank was also instrumental in the Bristol-Myers Squibb merger of 1989 and the Hoffmann-La Roche acquisition of Genentech in 1990 . [ 12 ]
#Text=At the time , the merger of an established pharmaceutical company with a younger biotechnology company was highly unusual .
#Text=It has been described by Frank as a " strategy of convergence " . [ 13 ]

column1: #Text=After Barclays Capital bought Lehman 's U.S. capital markets unit in September 2008 , [ 14 ] [ 15 ]
#Text=Frank became a vice chair at Barclays Capital . [ 16 ]
#Text=As of March 18 , 2009 , Frederick Frank and Mary Tanner joined Peter J. Solomon , of PJ SOLOMON to form a new practice focusing on pharmaceuticals and life sciences . [ 16 ]
#Text=Frank became a vice chairman at Peter J. Solomon , while Tanner became a managing director . [ 17 ]
#Text=As of January 15 , 2013 , Frederick Frank and Mary Tanner joined Burrill & Company . [ 18 ]
#Text=Frank became chair of Burrill Securities ( 2013- ) and vice chair of Burrill and Company ( January 15 , 2013- ) . [ 19 ]
#Text=Tanner became the Senior Managing Director of Burrill Securities and of Burrill & Company . [ 18 ]
#Text=As of 2014 , Frank and Tanner founded EVOLUTION Life Science Partners , and Frank became chair of the company . [ 4 ]
#Text=Frank has also served on numerous advisory groups and boards of directors . [ 19 ]
#Text=Philanthropy
#Text=As of October , 1997 , the non-profit Tanner Frank Foundation of New York City was granted charitable status . [ 20 ]
#Text=Frank has served on the board of advisors of the School of Management ( SOM ) at Yale University , and has given generously to SOM .
#Text=Gifts include the establishment of a language study fellowship and a visiting professorship in 1998 .
#Text=In 2007 , he established a professorship , [ 11 ]
#Text=which was first filled in 2009 when Gary Gorton became Yale 's first Frederick Frank Class of 1954 Professor of Management and Finance . [ 21 ]
#Text=On April 9 , 2012 Olav Sorenson became the inaugural holder of the Frank and Tanner Professor of Management . [ 22 ]
#Text=Awards and honors
#Text=2019 , Richard J. Bolte Sr. Award for supporting industries [ 4 ]
#Text=2006 , Gilda 's Club of New York City Visionary Award [ 19 ]
#Text=2005 , Top 100 living contributors to biotechnology , Reed Elsevier [ 5 ]
#Text=2004 , Albert Einstein Award from the Weizmann Institute of Science [ 19 ]
#Text=1998 , Outstanding Contributions in the Field of Immunology , Irvington Institute for Immunological Research [ 19 ] [ 5 ]
#Text=1997 , Hall of Fame Award , The Biotech Meeting in Laguna Niguel , California . [ 5 ] [ 6 ]
